abstract.p: This invention relates to an image display method comprising displaying a first image (I10) of an imaged zone in a first display window (S1), displaying a second image (I21) of only part of said imaged zone in a second display window (S2) distinct from said first display window (S1), a majority of said first image (I10) being refreshed at a lower refreshing rate than said second image (I21).

This invention relates to an image display method comprising displaying a first image (I10) of an imaged zone in a first display window (S1), displaying a second image (I21) of only part of said imaged zone in a second display window (S2) distinct from said first display window (S1), a majority of said first image (I10) being refreshed at a lower refreshing rate than said second image (I21).

description.p: The invention relates to image display methods, in particular to image display methods focusing on a region of interest (ROI) of an imaged zone within a more extended field of view (FOV) of this imaged zone. Preferably, the imaged zone is part of a body of a human being. The imaged zone can be a part of an object exposed to a radiation source. Radiation will be preferably X-ray radiation, but sources using other type of radiation can be used too.

In the preferred application field of the invention, imaging part of a body of a human being, the amount of radiation emitted by the source and received by patients whose body is imaged as well as operators manipulating the imaging system, should be reduced. Therefore, to reduce the amount of radiation received by the patient, one efficient way is to limit the exposure of the anatomical part of body to be imaged.

Minimizing the amount of ionizing radiation used during x-ray guided interventional procedure is of importance to protect both patients and operators. Several strategies can be used as part of standard radiation protection practice. In particular, collimating the x-ray beam to limit exposure to the anatomical region being treated is very effective as it limits the x-ray beam to the required area. However, this comes at the expense of not being able to see the surrounding anatomical context. In addition, collimating to the right anatomical area requires operator action. This is the reason why collimation is often underutilized, thus leading to larger than necessary exposed area.

In a prior art, for example described in American patent US 5412704, it is known to display one image showing at the same time the whole field of view of imaged zone as well as the more limited region of interest in the middle of the field of view. To be able to limit radiation exposure as well as to often update information on the region of interest, the refreshing rate of the region of interest of the imaged zone is notably higher than the refreshing rate of the rest of the field of view surrounding the region of interest of the imaged zone.

However, this prior art, even if satisfactory at first sight, will reveal a drawback when considered with deepest attention, what has be done according to the invention. When displaying both region of interest and field of view of imaged zone in a single image on a single display window, region of interest being within the center of field of view, choosing the size of the image to be displayed leads to a compromise. Either a limited size of displayed image is chosen or a big size of displayed image is chosen. If a limited size of displayed image is chosen, then the size of the displayed region of interest on the screen may be too small to be easily exploited by the operator. If a big size of displayed image is chosen, then the screen may be too cumbersome. Of course, a compromise can be chosen in between; but for the relatively big size of image, the size of the displayed region of interest on the screen may then appear as too narrow. Besides, in this prior art, the region of interest is not displayed in optimal conditions; indeed, the size of the displayed region of interest on the screen is too small.
The object of the present invention is to alleviate at least partly the above mentioned drawbacks.

More particularly, the invention aims to show, on at least two different display windows of reasonable size, both the region of interest and the field of view, the region of interest being refreshed at a higher refreshing rate than the field of view. That way, both images can be optimized independently, the region of interest image so as to be easily exploited by the operator without needing too big a display window, and the field of view including the region of interest so as to locate the region of interest within the rest of field of view of imaged zone in a reasonable size display window, without impairing detailed exploitation of region of interest, since such detailed exploitation is no more performed in this display window.

This object is achieved with an image display method comprising displaying a first image of an imaged zone in a first display window, displaying a second image of only part of said imaged zone in a second display window distinct from said first display window, a majority of said first image being refreshed at a lower refreshing rate than said second image. In an option, all said first image is refreshed at a lower refreshing rate than said second image.

This object is also achieved with an image display system comprising a first display window adapted to display a first image of an imaged zone, a second display window, distinct from said first display window, adapted to display a second image of only part of said imaged zone, a refreshing system adapted to refresh a majority of said first image at a lower refreshing rate than said second image. In an option, all said first image is refreshed at a lower refreshing rate than said second image. Preferably, this image display system comprises a single collimating system which is adapted to collimate an electromagnetic beam which is sent on said imaged zone to capture said first and second images and which is also adapted to switch between said first and second images.

This object is also achieved with an imaging system comprising a radiation source adapted to radiate on an imaged zone, a radiation detector adapted to receive radiation from said imaged zone so as to detect a first image of said imaged zone and a second image of only part of said imaged zone, a collimating system adapted to collimate radiation emitted by said radiation source, a control system adapted to control said collimating device so as to refresh a majority of said first image detected by said radiation detector at a lower refreshing rate than said second image detected by said radiation detector, an image display system including a first display window adapted to display said first image received from said radiation detector and a second display window, distinct from said first display window, adapted to display said second image received from said radiation detector. In an option, all said first image is refreshed at a lower refreshing rate than said second image.
Preferred embodiments comprise one or more of the following features, which may be taken separately or in partial combination or in full combination.

Preferably, first refreshing rate of first image is at least twice smaller than second refreshing rate of second image, more preferably at least five times smaller, and even more preferably at least ten times smaller.

Preferably, said first image is displayed on a first display screen and said second image is displayed on a second display screen distinct from said first display screen. That way, both screens can be kept in very reasonable range of size, one bigger screen may cost more than two smaller screens.

Preferably, said second image is a zoom of only part of said first image. That way, while still keeping a reasonable size of display window and of associated screen, more optimal exploitation of information contained is said second image is made possible. Preferably, said second image is displayed over a larger or equal screen area than said first image. That way, while still keeping a reasonable size of display window and of associated screen, even more optimal exploitation of information contained is said second image is made possible. Other image processing can be applied on one of the images and not on the other. Other image processing can be applied on both images but in a first way on first image which is different from a second way on second image.
Preferably, a box framing said second image is displayed in said first image. That makes easier for the operator the quick location of region of interest within the rest of field of view.

Preferably, said imaged zone is part of a body of a human being. In this field, the level of radiation received by the imaged zone if particularly critical. Preferably, said imaged zone is imaged by medical X-ray imaging, preferably by medical dynamic X-ray imaging.

Preferably, an electromagnetic beam collimated with a collimating system is sent on said imaged zone to capture said first and second images and switching between said first and second images is performed with same said collimating system. First, this saves material resources in the global imaging system. Second, this is made possible by choosing a substantially lower refreshing rate for first image showing field of view, what is possible since field of view does not need such a high refreshing rate as region of interest, since it is to be used by the operator only from time to time and only to perform a rough localization of region of interest within field of view. Preferably, said collimated electromagnetic beam is pulsed at a pulse rate corresponding to a pulse period, a duration of opening or of shutting said collimating system is longer than the pulse period, preferably longer than two pulse periods, more preferably longer than five pulse periods. The duration of opening and shutting said collimating system should not be too long. Advantageously, the duration of opening or of shutting said collimating system is shorter than twenty pulse periods, more preferably shorter than ten pulse periods.

Preferably, one or more pulses are not sent during opening and shutting of said collimating system. This allows avoiding emitting radiation that will produce intermediate images, images intermediate between region of interest and field of view, which indeed are not useful and need not be used by the operator. This helps make sure that all the radiation received by the imaged zone is "useful" radiation, which is radiation used to make images which are useful and which will be exploited by the operator, because those images are really needed and not only because those images have to be exploited since radiation has been emitted.

Preferably, said first image is a single and full capture of said imaged zone, especially when one or more pulses are not sent during opening and shutting of said collimating system. Alternatively, said first image is a combination of several captured images, some of them containing only part of said imaged zone. This combination allows to refresh parts of field of view closer to region of interest to be refreshed more often than parts of field of view farther from region of interest, what can be useful, since the parts of field of view closer to region of interest are more critical than the parts of field of view farther from region of interest.

First image representing the field of view of an imaged zone and second image representing a region of interest of the field of view of this imaged zone, region of interest being smaller than field of view and region of interest being a portion only of field of view, first image being refreshed at a first refreshing rate smaller than a second refreshing rate of second image, there are several embodiments for the refreshing rate of the region of interest located within the field of view in the first image.

In a first embodiment, the region of interest in the first image is refreshed at the first refreshing rate, that is at the same refreshing rate that the rest of the field of view. Manipulation of information in the first image is rather simple and consistent between field of view and region of interest. However, region of interest is not updated as much as it could.

In a second embodiment, the region of interest in the first image is refreshed at the second refreshing rate, that is at the same refreshing rate as the region of interest in the second image. Region of interest is updated as much as possible, but there may be some inconsistency between region of interest and field of view, because of too big a difference between first and second refreshing rates.

In a third embodiment, the region of interest in the first image is refreshed at a third refreshing rate, this third refreshing rate being greater than the first refreshing rate but being smaller than the second refreshing rate. Region of interest updating is an intermediate between first and second embodiments, and there is a more consistency between region of interest and field of view than in second embodiment but less than in first embodiment. This intermediate value between first and second refreshing rates may help to make a better compromise in some cases.

Preferably, capturing said first and second images is done by a detector, with no anti-scatter grid between imaged zone and detector. This option is specifically used when the part of a body which is x-rayed, is of reduced thickness.
Preferably, the collimating system is switching between said first image showing Field of View and said second image showing Region of Interest.

Said first image is being refreshed at a lower refreshing rate than said second image. To perform this, at some periods, preferably only part of imaged zone is refreshed, whereas other part of imaged zone is not refreshed. Preferably said other part of imaged zone receives no or little imaging beam. This is done preferably either by interposing blades between imaging beam source and other part of image zone or by interposing attenuating filters between imaging beam source and other part of image zone.

Another object of this invention is to propose means to automate collimation to a reduced area and at the same time show the region of interest in the broader anatomical context of the field of view of an imaged zone.

This object is achieved with an imaging method comprising displaying a first image of an imaged zone, displaying a second image of only part of said imaged zone, said first image being refreshed at a lower refreshing rate than said second image, sending an electromagnetic beam collimated with a collimating system on said imaged zone to capture said first and second images, performing switching between said first and second images with same said collimating system. This imaging method can display both first and second images either on the same display window or on two display windows distinct from each other. If the already existing collimator in imaging system is reused to perform the switching between first and second image, this imaging method could be implemented in existing imaging system as a software only feature, thus resulting in no product cost increase, provided image processing resources can accommodate image pasting.

Further features and advantages of the invention will appear from the following description of embodiments of the invention, given as nonlimiting examples, with reference to the accompanying drawings listed hereunder.

description.p: All figures 1 to 6 are shown with a region of interest ROI which is a centered square of the field of view FOV. Nevertheless, any other suitable way of delimiting region of interest ROI in the field of view FOV, for example a non-centered rectangle.

Fig. 1 shows an example of image including a region of interest within a field of view according to some embodiments of the invention. An imaged zone I corresponds to a field of view FOV including in its center a region of interest ROI. The field of view FOV covers 100% of the imaged zone I. The rest of field of view FOV corresponds to the periphery of the imaged zone surrounding the region of interest ROI. Here the region of interest ROI covers about 11 % of the whole field of view FOV, whereas the rest of field of view FOV covers about 89% of the whole field of view FOV which corresponds to the imaged zone I.

Fig. 2 shows an example of closing and opening of collimating device to make first and second images to be displayed according to some embodiments of the invention. Interventional x-ray imaging system will be operated in a new mode, in particular make use of off-the-shelf collimator and new display mode. X-ray radiation is pulsed at pulse rate P. The collimator will close and open cyclically during exposure. The global cyclic period is T which for example ranges from 5s to 10s. The closing and opening duration is τ which for example ranges from 0.5s to 1s. During closing period, the imaged zone goes from I1 corresponding to complete field of view FOV to I2 corresponding to region of interest ROI, going through intermediate images 13 and I4. During opening period, the imaged zone goes from I2 corresponding to region of interest ROI to I1 corresponding to complete field of view FOV, going through intermediate images I4 and I3.

Indeed, soon after the operator depresses the x-ray pedal to start imaging the patient, the collimator blades automatically move until reaching a defined region of interest ROI position corresponding to image I2. It is not the object of this invention to specifically describe how the region of interest ROI is selected, especially its size and position. It can simply be a zone located at the center of the image whose area is, e.g., 1/4thto on 1/9th of the full field of view FOV. Another form, different from a centered square, can be used too, for example a non-centered rectangle, or a centered rectangle or a non-centered square. Although it is desirable that the collimation blades move quickly from full field of view FOV position corresponding to image I1 to region of interest ROI corresponding to image I2 position, it is not necessary that this happens between two x-ray exposures, e.g. 67 milliseconds if the patient is imaged at 15 images per second. While collimation blades close, the image processor of the x-ray system keeps memory of successive images, here for example 13 and I4, and, in a given image, replaces the dark area due to the presence of the collimator blades by the most recent image information available prior to the blades reaching this position.

This allows showing the region of interest ROI at nominal frame rate in its broader anatomical context encompassing the full field of view FOV. As this information can become quickly irrelevant because of natural anatomical motion or because the operator wants to image a different zone, the collimator will open to full field of view FOV every few seconds automatically, or based on changes of imaging conditions, for example table top or gantry motion, or under specific operator action, for example change of field of view FOV size, change of region of interest ROI size or position, etc.... During this process, the image is refreshed using the same process as already described. This process is repeated as the operator continues pressing the x-ray pedal. Typically, the collimator may close or open within half a second and the process may be repeated every 5 seconds. The curve C shows the Dose Area Product DAP plotted versus time.

Although this is not the object of this invention to present specific image processing algorithms, two possible, simple implementations of the processing to eliminate collimator blades from the image are mentioned. The first one is a form of peak detection that retains the maximum pixel value outside the region of interest ROI. Another possibility is a modified traditional fluoroscopic noise reduction filter which is a recursive low pass filter. Obviously, more sophisticated processing is possible.

Fig. 3 shows a curve showing the radiation dose reduction when using different refreshing rates for first and second images to be displayed according to some embodiments of the invention. The duration of opening or of shutting said collimating system is notably longer than the pulse period. The curve C of figure 2 is shown again, whereas the saved dose SD of radiation received by the imaged zone is shown too. The exposed area EA, expressed in percentage, is plotted versus the time, expressed in seconds. Clearly, refreshing full field of view FOV at a notable lower rate than the region of interest ROI allows for a notably high saved dose.

Interestingly enough, this mode can allow operating without anti-scatter grid. When exposed area becomes small, typically 12 cm or less, it becomes advantageous to remove the anti-scatter grid for small patient thickness, because scatter rejection will not so easily make up for the signal loss due to grid absorption. Indeed, contrast-to-noise can be made better without grid at equivalent image quality and lower dose, in about 10-20% range. Therefore, the propose scheme could at the same time provide lower Dose Area Product DAP, representative of the level of radiation received by the imaged zone, and lower skin dose in some circumstances, particularly in pediatric imaging. The curve C is showing the level of this Dose Area Product DAP which of course much greater during closing and opening phase than during region of interest ROI stable position.

Moreover, the proposed mode could be further leveraged to provide means for scatter radiation correction in the image. It is known art that scatter can be estimated by measuring signal at the location of the collimator blades. Then correction can be applied to the region of interest ROI based on this measurement. One simple approach is to subtract the mean measurement from the readings at the region of interest ROI. Other more sophisticated methods exist.

Fig. 4 shows an example of displayed image according to the prior art. On a screen S0, in the same display window, a first image I10 representing the field of view FOV of an imaged zone is displayed. In the center of the first image I10, a second image I20 representing the region of interest ROI is displayed. In the second image I20, there is an object O1 that can be seen. This object O1 is relatively small, so if it is to be seen more clearly by the operator, the operator will have to zoom on second image I20 which will be cover at least part of the surrounding field of view FOV which will then be no more visible by the operator. Part of first image I10 surrounding second image I20 is refreshed at a lower rate than second image I20. Such factors as low refreshing rate, pasting of images taken at different times, not clearly defined blade edges due to non-punctual x-ray source as well as off-focal radiation, etc. will result into degradation of image quality, with exception of the region of interest ROI.

Fig. 5 shows an example of displayed images according to some embodiments of the invention. On a screen S1, or in a first display window of a given screen, a first image I10 representing the field of view FOV of an imaged zone is displayed. In the center of the first image I10, a second image I22 representing the region of interest ROI is displayed. In the second image I22, there is an object O1 that can be seen. This object O1 is relatively small, but it can be seen more precisely on a second screen S2, or in a second display window different from first display window but on same given screen, a second image I21, preferably zoomed, representing the region of interest ROI, is displayed. Here, object O1 can be seen more clearly, especially with fewer artefacts or without any of the artefacts which can be created at the border B between images I10 and I22.

Screen S1 is the reference monitor showing region of interest ROI in the anatomical context of field of view FOV. Screen S2 is the live monitor showing in detail and or without artefacts the region of interest ROI alone, independently of the field of view FOV. This is quite an interesting mode because the operator requires maximum image quality for the region of interest ROI and can get by with reduced quality for the anatomical background shown in the field of view FOV. The live image I21 is where its eye will focus and the reduced rate image I10 including image I22 will serve as reference from time to time. The border B between the image I22 representing the region of interest ROI of first image I10 and the rest of image I10 may be indicated by graphics on the first image I10, for example through a dotted box framing B. From a practical standpoint, two different monitors may be used, or alternatively, a large monitor screen with two fully distinct display windows, one for the first image I10 including image I22, and the other one for the second image I21.

Fig. 6 shows examples of curves showing the evolution of the resulting Dose Area Product DAP with respect to the frame rate between second image and first image. The duration of opening or of shutting said collimating system is notably longer than the pulse period. The resulting Dose Area Product DAP, expressed in percentage, is plotted versus the image frame rate IRF, expressed in Hertz. Resulting DAP shows the percentage of DAP remaining versus the nominal DAP without collimating system closing and opening. The three curves DAP1, DAP2 and DAP3, correspond respectively to three different ratios of surfaces between second image and first image, here 10%, 25% and 40%. The highest the ratio between ROI and FOV areas is, the highest the resulting DAP is relatively to the nominal DAP , while keeping in mind that resulting DAP remains inferior to nominal DAP, without collimation opening and closing, and the lowest is also the factor by which the nominal DAP is divided.

The exposed area of the patient is limited. Radiation is not reduced at the region of interest ROI, with exception of the proposed removal of the anti-scatter grid, but unnecessary exposure to surrounding anatomy is limited. From a practical standpoint, this will provide significant reduction of the Dose Area Product DAP. At first order (not accounting for the discrete nature of the x-ray exposure), Dose Area Product DAP reduction as defined by the ratio of DAP in the automated region of interest ROI mode to Dose Area Product DAP at full field of view FOV can be approximated by the following equation: DAP Reduction≅α+2⁢τT⁢13-α+23⁢α32

Where α is the ratio between region of interest ROI and full field of view FOV areas, T is the period of the close open collimator blade cycle, and τ is the time required by the collimator to fully close or open.

Using α = 1/9, T = 5 s, τ = 0.5 s: approximate resulting Dose Area Product DAP is approximately 16% of nominal DAP. Therefore, such a mode can easily divide Dose Area Product DAP by a factor of 5, depending on characteristics of the collimator, for instance speed, area of the selected region of interest ROI, refreshing rate, and image frame rate. In particular, in very low frame rate modes, collimator closure can be viewed as instantaneous, because happening between to x-ray exposures, thus providing optimal dose reduction conditions.
The invention has been described with reference to preferred embodiments. However, many variations are possible within the scope of the invention.

claim.claim-text: Image display method comprising: - displaying a first image (I10) of an imaged zone in a first display window (S1), - displaying a second image (I21) of only part of said imaged zone in a second display window (S2) distinct from said first display window (S1), - a majority of said first image (I10) being refreshed at a lower refreshing rate than said second image (I21).

Image display method according to claim 1, wherein said first image (I10) is displayed on a first display screen (S1), and said second image (I21) is displayed on a second display screen (S2) distinct from said first display screen (S1).
Image display method according to any preceding claim, wherein said second image (I21) is a zoom of only part of said first image (I10).
Image display method according to any preceding claim, wherein said second image (I21) is displayed over a larger or equal screen area than said first image (I10).
Image display method according to any preceding claim, wherein a box framing (B) said second image (I21) is displayed in said first image (I10).
Image display method according to any preceding claim, wherein said imaged zone is part of a body of a human being.
Image display method according to any preceding claim, wherein said imaged zone is imaged by medical X-ray imaging, preferably by medical dynamic X-ray imaging.

Image display method according to any preceding claim, wherein an electromagnetic beam collimated with a collimating system is sent on said imaged zone to capture said first (I10) and second (I21) images, and switching between said first (I10) and second (I21) images is performed with same said collimating system.

Image display method according to claim 8, wherein said collimated electromagnetic beam is pulsed at a pulse rate (P) corresponding to a pulse period, and a duration of opening or of shutting said collimating system is longer than the pulse period, preferably longer than two pulse periods.
Image display method according to claim 9, wherein one or more pulses are not sent during opening and shutting of said collimating system.
Image display method according to any of claims 1 to 10, wherein said first image (I10) is a combination of several captured images, some of them containing only part of said imaged zone.
Image display method according to any of claims 1 to 10, wherein said first image (I10) is a single and full capture of said imaged zone.
Image display method according to any preceding claims, wherein at least an image processing correction is applied on said second image (I21) only and not on first image (I10).

Image display system comprising: - a first display window (S1) adapted to display a first image (I10) of an imaged zone, - a second display window (S2), distinct from said first display window (S1), adapted to display a second image (I21) of only part of said imaged zone, - a refreshing system adapted to refresh a majority of said first image (I10) at a lower refreshing rate than said second image (I21).

Image display system comprising according to claim 14 wherein it further comprises a single collimating system which is adapted to collimate an electromagnetic beam which is sent on said imaged zone to capture said first (I10) and second (I21) images and which is also adapted to switch between said first (I10) and second (I21) images.

Imaging system comprising: - a radiation source adapted to radiate on an imaged zone, - a radiation detector adapted to receive radiation from said imaged zone so as to detect a first image (I10) of said imaged zone and a second image (I21) of only part of said imaged zone, - a collimating system adapted to collimate radiation emitted by said radiation source, - a control system adapted to control said collimating device so as to refresh a majority of said first image (I10) detected by said radiation detector at a lower refreshing rate than said second image (I21) detected by said radiation detector, - an image display system including: - a first display window (S1) adapted to display said first image (I10) received from said radiation detector, - a second display window (S2), distinct from said first display window (S1), adapted to display said second image (I21) received from said radiation detector.
